#### Section 1: Interparticle and intersurface forces: the missing link
When I was a student, I thought that van der Waals forces were relevant
only to atoms and molecules. It didn't occur to me that the concepts of
dipole-dipole and London dispersion forces applied to small particles,
to say nothing of large objects like fingertips and construction
materials. Well, such forces absolutely manifest on this large, "human,"
scale. Here, we will learn how to calculate the forces between
nanoparticles and large surfaces. We will learn the relative strengths
of these forces, how to engineer them to make stable systems of
nanoparticles, and a bit of the theory as to how they operate. For a
video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/CfMqxMJRfkc)

As much as I enjoyed thinking about atoms, molecules, and reactions
between them in my classes as a chemistry major in college, a part of me
found these courses unsatisfying. The dictionary definition of chemistry
is "the study of the structure and properties of matter, and the changes
that it undergoes." However, endless acid-base titrations, Lewis dot
structures, and balancing equations didn't seem to come close to
explaining the "properties of matter." I wanted to know how ants and
spiders stuck to the ceiling, why superglue didn't work under water, and
how my body didn't congeal despite my cells being 30% solids. You know,
the stuff that most teenagers think about.

In order to answer these questions, one needs to know not about covalent
interactions---i.e., chemistry---but of *noncovalent* ones. While
chemistry classes make us think that chemical reactions are happening
all the time, it's pretty rare that we observe them in action. (Of
course chemical reactions are at the core of chemical manufacturing and
are ubiquitous in biological systems. Cooking involves some chemical
change, but even something as simple as cooking an egg---denaturing its
proteins using heat---involves noncovalent interactions.) Indeed, most
"everyday phenomena" are based on noncovalent interactions. When I was a
high school and college student, I knew something was missing from my
chemistry curriculum, but I quite literally didn't know what it was.

Sure, we were all taught about van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonds, and
the other interactions that formed the basis of Chapter 2. But it didn't
seem that they had anything to do with real life. I knew that van der
Waals forces existed between atoms and molecules, and were responsible
at least for the forces between atoms of noble gases, like helium and
argon. But did van der Waals forces exist between objects you could
touch? Is the sticky feeling of tape or your skin on a hot day the
result of van der Waals force? Or is it something else? If van der Waals
forces are so weak---argon is a gas, after all---then what explains the
hardness of hard candy, which are supposedly held together by nothing
but van der Waals forces (so-called "van der Waals'' solids)?
Do you have any questions?

#### Section 2: Van der Waals forces between particles and surfaces
It is a relatively simple conceptual jump to go from forces between
ions, atoms, and molecules to forces between nanoparticles (and even
macroscopic objects). In order to obtain the potential energies and
forces between objects larger than atoms and molecules, we have to add
up all the individual forces between the atoms or molecules that make up
the larger particles. To do this, we start by assuming that each atom or
molecule interacts with every atom or molecule in the opposing particle.
We use integral calculus[^3.2.1] to add up all the forces, and get an
equation in terms of the van der Waals coefficient, $C_{VDW}$.

### 3.2.1. Interactions involving curved objects

It is often useful to know the interaction energies between surfaces
containing one or more curved surfaces: spheres, hemispheres, and things
that can be approximated as such. Given the spherical shapes of atoms,
it may be tempting to just take equations (2.3), (2.6), and (2.7) and
scale by the number of particles in each object. Unfortunately, this
will give us the wrong answer. The reason is that the centers of the
objects might be centimeters or meters away from each other. Thus, the
vast majority of atoms in any macroscopic surface contribute effectively
zero to the van der Waals interaction. Such potential energies fall off
to essentially nothing after only a few tens of nanometers.

Nevertheless, it is possible to derive equations for the interaction
energies for most geometries of particles one is likely to encounter.
For example, below is the equation for the energy between two spherical
particles of equal radii, made of the same material.

(Equation 3.1) $$W(D)=-\frac{\pi^2C_{VDW}\rho^2R}{12D}$$

where $W(D)$ is the interaction potential energy and $D$ is the distance
between the surfaces of the particles. We use a big $W$ as opposed to a
small $w$ to emphasize that these are energies between particles much
larger than atoms and molecules, and we use $D$ as the *separation
between the surfaces*. We do not use $r$, the center-to-center distance,
because the centers of two nanoscopic or macroscopic objects could be
very far from the surfaces, and do not contribute much to the total
energy. Note that the interaction energy falls off as $1/D$ rather than
the inverse factor of $r^6$ we saw for the van der Waals energy for
individual atoms and molecules (i.e., $1/r^6$). Thus, the interaction
between surfaces particles maintains its strength for relative large
distances.

### 3.2.2. The Hamaker constant

The terms for density, $\pi$, and the van der Waals coefficient,
$C_{VDW}$, appear so often in these equations that we define a new
quantity, the Hamaker constant, $A$, which contains all of these
quantities:

(Equation 3.2) $$A=\pi^2C_{VDW}\rho^2$$

Thus, the equation for the energy between two identical spheres can be
written as

(Equation 3.3) $$W(D)=-\frac{AR}{12D}$$

Each Hamaker constant comes from a unique combination of three different
materials: two of which are the two objects interacting, and the third
is the medium in which the interaction occurs (e.g., air, vacuum,
water). For example, two silicon dioxide nanoparticles interacting in
water would have the Hamaker constant $A$ $_{SiO_2-H_2O-SiO_2}$ ,
regardless of the size or shape of the particles. How do we go about
calculating the Hamaker constant, $A$? The answer is that we don't; we
look it up in a table. There are only a fairly limited number of Hamaker
constants that nanoengineers could possibly care about: particles of
silicon, gold, silver, copper, platinum, organic nanoparticles, etc.,
interacting in air, vacuum, water, or in a solvent.

Thus, the use of $A$ instead of various factors of $C_{VDW}$, $\pi$, and
$\rho$ greatly simplifies the expressions for energies between objects
larger than molecules. Most Hamaker constants are on the order of
10$^{-19}$ J in air or vacuum. The reason the Hamaker constant doesn't
vary that much between materials is that the equation for $A$ contains
two competing criteria: the van der Waals coefficient, $C_{VDW}$, and
the density $\rho$. $C_{VDW}$ is proportional to the square of the
electronic polarizability, which is proportional to the square of the
volume. On the other hand, $\rho$ is proportional to the inverse of the
volume. When $\rho$ is squared in equation (3.2), you get something
proportional to the inverse of the square of the volume. So, the two
terms roughly cancel out and you end up with some factor times
10$^{-19}$.

### 3.2.3. Converting energy to forces between surfaces

As objects get bigger and start looking more like engineering systems
than like chemical systems, we tend to become more interested in
*forces* rather than *energies*. In Chapter 2, we defined the force as
the negative rate of change of the energy with respect to interparticle
separation. Using this relationship between force and energy as before,
equation (2.2), convince yourself that the force can be written as

(Equation 3.4) $$F(D)_{sphere-sphere}=-\frac{AR}{12D^2}$$

The energy of a sphere interacting with a flat surface arises often in
nanoengineering. The round object can also be taken to be the radius of
curvature of a tip, or some microscopic bit of roughness.

(Equation 3.5) $$W(D)_{sphere-surface}=-\frac{AR}{6D}$$

As a homework assignment, see if you can derive the equation for the
force from equation (3.5).

### 3.2.4. Interactions between flat objects

Finally, consideration of the energy of two flat surfaces interacting
yields:

(Equation 3.6)
$$W(D)_{flat-flat}=-\frac{A}{12 \pi D^2} \text{ per unit area}$$

Please note that the equation for the two flat surfaces above has units
of *energy per unit area*. That is, a two-dimensional energy density.
When converted to force, we have force per unit area, which is also
called pressure:

(Equation 3.7) $$F(D)_{flat-flat}=P(D)=-\frac{A}{6\pi D^{3}}$$

Equations (3.6) and (3.7) are profound in the following sense: if the
two interacting surfaces are made of the same material, then equation
(3.6) represent the *cohesive energy density* per cross sectional area
of the material. Then, equation (3.7) is the *cohesive pressure* of two
pieces of material with perfectly smooth surfaces. For a typical van der
Waals solid like a piece of hard candy, the cohesive pressure is
huge---on the order of 1,000 atmospheres! Now, of course, if you have
two broken pieces of hard candy and, assuming they are not sticky due to
humidity or high temperature, try to stick them together, they probably
will not stick very well. Or, certainly not with 1,000 atmospheres of
pressure! On the other hand, if you take an intact piece of hard candy
and attempt to break it apart with two pairs of pliers---*without
bending it*---you will find that it is almost impossible. The reason it
will not fuse together if already broken but will be nearly impossible
to break apart if initially unbroken is not because the two scenarios
are operating under different force laws. The reason is that when
putting two pieces together, all it takes is one little nanoscale
protrusion or defect for the whole surface to be misaligned. If this
misalignment happens, the probability of every molecule on one surface
being *in van der Waals contact* with a molecule on the other surface is
vanishingly small. Thus, we don't achieve nearly the adhesive pressure
predicted by equation (3.7).

As a preview to the next chapter, the energy per unit area as shown in
equation (3.6), comes up a lot. In particular, this quantity is two
times the **surface energy density** of the two surfaces after they are
broken apart. If the material is a liquid, the surface energy density
has the same value as the **surface tension**, which is responsible for
a range of phenomena, from the spherical shape of water droplets in the
sky, to the capillarity responsible for flow in rapid antigen tests for
the coronavirus that causes COVID-19, to the mechanism by which water
striders and other animals "walk on water."

### 3.2.5. Summary of particle geometries

The scenarios described in equations (3.3) through (3.7) should cover
\>90% of scenarios you are likely to encounter in your career in
nanoengineering, and 100% of the scenarios you will encounter in this
course. Figure (3.1) depicts these scenarios.

(Figure 3.1)

#### Section 3: Electric double layer forces
You might wonder why---since van der Waals forces are attractive---any
solution or suspension of nanoparticles like paint or milk can be stable
at all. In fact, human cells are something like 30% solid material! If
van der Waals forces are attractive and ubiquitous, why does not all of
this solid material just clump up, sink to the bottom, or float to the
top, as the case may be? The reason is that in such suspensions, there
are repulsive forces that prevent aggregation or coagulation of the
particles. One of these forces is the **electric double layer force
(EDL)**, which occurs between all nanoparticles and surfaces in any
aqueous environment. Stated briefly and expanded upon below, the EDL
force arises because of a repulsive interaction of entropic origin. A
diffuse layer of **counterions** surrounds charged particles that are
immersed in water. Compression of these diffuse layers when two charged
particles are brought close together, as we will see, results in a
repulsive force, which keeps the particles from clumping together.

### 3.3.1. Origin of the EDL force

The EDL force arises because of the entropic repulsion of clouds of ions
which surround charged particles or surfaces. In aqueous media, any
surface placed inside will take on charges which are fixed to the
surface. These surface charges are called **co-ions**. The charge of
each co-ion is counterbalanced by a **counterion**. This pairing ensures
electrical neutrality of the entire system (that is, the bound charges
at the surface and the counterions have opposite signs). For example,
when solid particles covered in --NH $_{2}$ groups are placed in an
aqueous solution, the basic nitrogen atom (specifically its lone pair)
sucks some number of H atoms from water. This acid-base reaction
produces positively charged surfaces (-NH$_{3}^{+}$) and negatively
charged counterions (OH$^{-}$). When the solid particles are really
close, such that the outside surfaces of the particles can be
approximated as two giant parallel plates, the OH$^{-}$ groups repel
from each other against the sides of the solid particles.[^3.3.1] In
solution at a finite temperature, entropy will ensure that the OH$^{-}$
counterions diffuse some short distance away from the surface bearing
the positive charge. When the large surfaces get closer together, the
diffuse clouds of counterions get squeezed and the individual OH$^{-}$
ions have less room to move around (Figure (3.2)). Entropically, this
situation is unfavorable, so there is a net repulsive force between the
surfaces. This force gets stronger with a greater surface charge density
(more counterions). On the other hand, the force gets weaker with
increasing electrolyte (i.e., salt) concentration in the solution.

(Figure 3.2) 
>>>image(EDL.png.0)

Our treatment of the EDL force is going to be largely qualitative in
this course. Suffice it to say that for every equation for the van der
Waals interaction involving spheres interacting with spheres, spheres
interacting with flat surfaces, etc., there is a corresponding equation
for the EDL interaction. These expressions get very complicated for our
purposes (they contain, for example, the highly unusual *tanh* function)
and will not be discussed here. While we will not present any equations,
we will say that the equations for the EDL interactions depend on the
surface charge density and the electrolyte concentration in solution.
Once calculated, they return values in units of energy (J) or force (N).
To get the total energy of interaction which includes both VDW and EDL
contributions, you just add them up (see Section (3.4)).

### 3.3.2. The Debye length

The characteristic thickness of the diffuse layer of counterions is
called the **Debye length, $\kappa^{-1}$**. The Debye length is a
measure of how rapidly away from the surface the halo of counterions
decays. It is not a measure of how many ions are in the cloud to begin
with. Recall that the fundamental reason the EDL interaction is
repulsive is because of the entropic unfavorability of confining this
layer of counterions. That is, when these layers get pinched---as in the
approach of two particles---the ions lose degrees of freedom. The
repulsive force that results can be increased in one of two ways. The
first way is to pinch the halo of counterions even more so when the
particles come nearly into contact (thus reducing the entropy of the
layer in the final state). The second way is to make the layer around
each particle thicker to begin with (thus increasing the entropy of the
initial state). The easiest way to tune the thickness of the counterion
layer is by adjusting the electrolyte (i.e., salt) concentration in the
medium.

#### Reducing the EDL repulsion by "salting out"

The salt concentration in the medium has a direct effect on the
thickness of the counterion layer surrounding each surface in water.
Just like the origin of the repulsive force, the reason is entropic.
Consider the reason why the layer of counterions is diffuse to begin
with. Pure electrostatics would predict that the counterions in the gap
between particles would be pushed away from each other as far as
possible. Just as the extra electrons on a conductor push each other
apart so that they are all at the surface (think of a steel ball bearing
with a lot of extra electrons), the counterions in gaps between surfaces
push each other apart. The fact that we are in a liquid medium at a
finite temperature encourages the counterions to drift a little bit away
from the surfaces (i.e., entropy). Hold that thought.

Now, consider the addition of a bunch of extra ions---both positive and
negative, as in Na$^{+}$ and Cl$^{-}$---into the solution. With all
those extra ions around, *there are many more ways that the original
layer of counterions could remain pushed apart, pinned to the opposing
surfaces*, as predicted by electrostatics alone. So, there is a
re-balancing between the driving force of electrostatics (which want the
counterions to be pushed in a very thin layer toward the surface) and
entropy (which want the counterions to be as diffuse as possible). More
salt in solution means more microstates, overall, so there is less of an
entropic benefit for the counterions to form a diffuse layer. Thus, they
become more and more pinned to the opposing surface, and the Debye
length shrinks. As the counterion layer becomes thinner, the EDL force
becomes weaker. If the EDL force becomes weak enough, the van der Waals
force will dominate, and the surfaces will be attracted to each other on
average. This situation is called an **unstable colloid** and the
process of making colloids precipitate by increasing the electrolyte
concentration is called "salting out." The balance between EDL forces
and VDW forces is analyzed using DLVO theory, as described in the next
section.[^3.3.2]

[^3.3.1]: In introductory electromagnetism, you will learn or have learned
    that charges in a metallic object---such as a ball bearing---try to
    get as far away from each other as possible by going to the surface.
    The same thing is happening in the case of the OH$^{-}$ ions.

[^3.3.2]: A note on terminology: a "colloid" is the whole suspension,
    including the solvent. A "colloidal particle" is a single particle.
Do you have any questions?
So to make the debye length greater could one just add more salt?

Actually, adding more salt decreases the Debye length. The textbook explains that increasing salt concentration reduces the thickness of the counterion layer, weakening the EDL force. Can you review the "Reducing the EDL repulsion by 'salting out'" section for more details?
so the Na+ takes the counterions and as such there are less counterions for the debye length?

Not quite. The Na+ and Cl- ions don't replace the counterions. Instead, they affect the distribution of counterions. The textbook explains that more salt provides more ways for counterions to remain close to the surface, reducing the entropic benefit of a diffuse layer. Can you reread that section and let me know if anything is still unclear?
What I'm saying is that the Na+ attracts the counterions so there are less for the halo around the molecule?

I see your reasoning, but that's not quite correct. The Na+ and Cl- don't directly attract or replace counterions. Instead, their presence reduces the entropic drive for counterions to spread out. The counterions remain, but in a thinner layer. Does this distinction make sense?
Could you elaborate a little on the entropic drive

Certainly. Entropy favors a more dispersed state for counterions. Without salt, counterions spread out to maximize entropy. Adding salt provides more ways for the system to be disordered overall, so counterions can stay closer to the surface without losing as much entropy. This results in a thinner counterion layer. Does this help clarify the concept?
what is a microstate and how does it relate to entropy

Great question! A microstate is a specific arrangement of particles in a system. Entropy is related to the number of possible microstates - more microstates mean higher entropy. In this context, adding salt increases the number of possible arrangements (microstates) for all ions in the solution. Can you see how this might affect the counterion distribution?
how does adding salt increase the microstates

Adding salt introduces more particles (Na+ and Cl- ions) into the solution. Each new particle can occupy different positions, dramatically increasing the total number of possible arrangements (microstates) in the system. This increase in microstates leads to higher overall entropy. Does this explanation help clarify the concept?
so the increase in entropy has nothing to do with the charge of the salt ions?

You're on the right track. The increase in entropy is primarily due to the additional particles, not their charge. However, the charges do play a role in the overall electrostatic interactions. The textbook discusses this balance between electrostatics and entropy. Would you like to explore this interplay further?
yes

Great! The textbook discusses how electrostatics want counterions close to the surface, while entropy favors dispersion. Salt ions add more particles (increasing entropy) and affect this balance. Their charges influence the electrostatic landscape. Can you think of how these factors might interact to affect the counterion distribution?
how do their charges influence the electrostatic landscape

The salt ions (Na+ and Cl-) create additional electrostatic interactions in the solution. They can screen the charges of the surface and counterions, reducing the long-range electrostatic effects. This screening allows counterions to stay closer to the charged surface without as much repulsion from other counterions. Does this help explain their influence?
yes but if there are more counterions wouldn't the edl increase?

Good thinking, but remember, we're not adding more counterions. The salt ions (Na+ and Cl-) are different from the original counterions. They don't increase the EDL, but rather compress it by allowing the original counterions to stay closer to the surface. This actually decreases the EDL force. Does this distinction make sense now?
how does compression cause the edl to go down

The EDL force arises from the entropy loss when counterion layers are compressed. When salt compresses the layer initially, there's less entropy to lose when surfaces approach. This results in a weaker repulsive force. The textbook explains this in the "Reducing the EDL repulsion by 'salting out'" section. Does this help clarify?
so is it that by increasing entropy there are more microstates that don't involve a diffuse halo?

Exactly! You've got it. By adding salt, we increase the overall entropy of the system, providing more microstates where the counterions can remain close to the surface without a significant entropy penalty. This reduces the need for a diffuse halo to maximize entropy. Well done on connecting these concepts!

#### Section 4: DLVO forces
A suspension of nanoparticles in solution---including paint, milk,
COVID-19 vaccine formulations, and other ubiquitous products---is called
a colloid. The forces between these particles are generally a
combination of attractive forces due to van der Waals interactions and
repulsive forces due to electric double layer forces. The forces exist
independently, so to get the energy, you can add up the energies of the
VDW and EDL interactions. The total force is called the DLVO (Derjaguin,
Landau, Verwey, Overbeek) force, named after four scientists you don't
need to remember the names of but can look up on Wikipedia. You just add
up the contributions from the VDW and EDL interactions as follows:

(Equation 3.8) $$W_{DLVO}(D)=W_{VDW}(D)+W_{EDL}(D)$$

And to get the force, you can add up the forces (Equation 3.9)
$$F_{DLVO}(D)=F_{VDW}(D)+F_{EDL}(D)$$ The total energy can be plotted as
shown in Figure (3.3), below.

(Figure 3.3) 
>>>image(DLVO curve.png.0)

Each DLVO curve, from left to right, has a primary minimum, a barrier,
and a secondary minimum. Basically, if the repulsive force dominates the
interaction, then the colloid is called **stable** meaning the particles
will not aggregate, coalesce, coagulate, or **flocculate**.[^3.4.1]
Sometimes, however, the EDL force is not enough to keep the VDW force
from producing an unstable colloid, and other repulsive interactions
must be engineered into the system.

[^3.4.1]: My favorite word in science.
Do you have any questions?
what does the primary minimum represent

The primary minimum in the DLVO curve represents the state where particles are in close contact and strongly attracted to each other. It's where aggregation or flocculation is likely to occur. Do you understand why this happens?
not quite

Okay, let's break it down. The primary minimum occurs when attractive van der Waals forces overcome repulsive forces at very close distances. This results in particles sticking together. Can you think of any real-world examples where this might be important?
paint?

Excellent example! In paint, we often want to prevent the primary minimum to keep particles dispersed. This maintains paint quality and prevents settling. Can you think of how we might achieve this based on the DLVO theory?
is the secondary minimum where repulsive forces take over?

Not quite. The secondary minimum is actually a shallow attractive well at a larger distance. It's where particles can loosely associate without fully aggregating. The repulsive forces dominate in the energy barrier between the primary and secondary minima. Does this help clarify the curve?
so the primary minimum is where attractive forces dominate?

Exactly! You've got it. The primary minimum is where attractive forces (mainly van der Waals) strongly dominate, causing particles to stick tightly together. This is typically what we try to avoid in stable colloids. Does this understanding help you see how it relates to the overall DLVO theory?
so where does the primary repulsive happen

The primary repulsion occurs at the energy barrier, which is the peak between the primary and secondary minima. This is where the electric double layer repulsion is strongest relative to the van der Waals attraction. Does that help clarify the different regions of the DLVO curve?
so when repulsive forces take over the energy is at the top of the barrier?

Correct! The peak of the energy barrier is where repulsive forces are strongest relative to attractive forces. This barrier prevents particles from reaching the primary minimum, keeping the colloid stable. Can you think of why this is important for certain applications?
will molecule flocculate in the second minimum

Good question! In the secondary minimum, particles can weakly associate but not permanently aggregate. This can lead to reversible flocculation. It's less stable than the primary minimum, so particles can separate more easily. How might this affect colloidal behavior?
so is the second minimum where the vdw overcome the edl

Not quite. In the secondary minimum, VDW forces slightly exceed EDL forces, but at a larger distance than the primary minimum. It's a weak attraction, not a complete overcoming. The textbook explains this balance. Would you like to review that section together?

#### Section 6: Outlook
In this chapter, we learned that van der Waals interactions were not
just weak forces between molecules that we learned about in chemistry.
In fact, they dominate all interactions between molecules in fluids
(liquids and gases) and even solids, assuming that it is not a covalent
solid like silicon or diamond. When van der Waals forces are combined
with EDL forces, along with other, "non-DLVO" interactions, we get a
near-complete picture of how particles and surfaces interact in a
liquid. The consequences of these forces go far beyond the stability of
colloids, however. We will find in the next chapter that surface
forces---in particular the van der Waals interaction---are also
responsible for the surface energy of solids and the surface tension of
liquids. These forces may seem weak compared to macroscopic forces like
the action of our muscles against gravity, but are so powerful on the
nanoscale as to be extraordinarily difficult to escape by mere atoms and
molecules stuck to a surface.

#### Section 1: Interparticle and intersurface forces: the missing link
When I was a student, I thought that van der Waals forces were relevant
only to atoms and molecules. It didn't occur to me that the concepts of
dipole-dipole and London dispersion forces applied to small particles,
to say nothing of large objects like fingertips and construction
materials. Well, such forces absolutely manifest on this large, "human,"
scale. Here, we will learn how to calculate the forces between
nanoparticles and large surfaces. We will learn the relative strengths
of these forces, how to engineer them to make stable systems of
nanoparticles, and a bit of the theory as to how they operate. For a
video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/CfMqxMJRfkc)

As much as I enjoyed thinking about atoms, molecules, and reactions
between them in my classes as a chemistry major in college, a part of me
found these courses unsatisfying. The dictionary definition of chemistry
is "the study of the structure and properties of matter, and the changes
that it undergoes." However, endless acid-base titrations, Lewis dot
structures, and balancing equations didn't seem to come close to
explaining the "properties of matter." I wanted to know how ants and
spiders stuck to the ceiling, why superglue didn't work under water, and
how my body didn't congeal despite my cells being 30% solids. You know,
the stuff that most teenagers think about.

In order to answer these questions, one needs to know not about covalent
interactions---i.e., chemistry---but of *noncovalent* ones. While
chemistry classes make us think that chemical reactions are happening
all the time, it's pretty rare that we observe them in action. (Of
course chemical reactions are at the core of chemical manufacturing and
are ubiquitous in biological systems. Cooking involves some chemical
change, but even something as simple as cooking an egg---denaturing its
proteins using heat---involves noncovalent interactions.) Indeed, most
"everyday phenomena" are based on noncovalent interactions. When I was a
high school and college student, I knew something was missing from my
chemistry curriculum, but I quite literally didn't know what it was.

Sure, we were all taught about van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonds, and
the other interactions that formed the basis of Chapter 2. But it didn't
seem that they had anything to do with real life. I knew that van der
Waals forces existed between atoms and molecules, and were responsible
at least for the forces between atoms of noble gases, like helium and
argon. But did van der Waals forces exist between objects you could
touch? Is the sticky feeling of tape or your skin on a hot day the
result of van der Waals force? Or is it something else? If van der Waals
forces are so weak---argon is a gas, after all---then what explains the
hardness of hard candy, which are supposedly held together by nothing
but van der Waals forces (so-called "van der Waals'' solids)?
Do you have any questions?

#### Section 2: Van der Waals forces between particles and surfaces
It is a relatively simple conceptual jump to go from forces between
ions, atoms, and molecules to forces between nanoparticles (and even
macroscopic objects). In order to obtain the potential energies and
forces between objects larger than atoms and molecules, we have to add
up all the individual forces between the atoms or molecules that make up
the larger particles. To do this, we start by assuming that each atom or
molecule interacts with every atom or molecule in the opposing particle.
We use integral calculus[^3.2.1] to add up all the forces, and get an
equation in terms of the van der Waals coefficient, $C_{VDW}$.

### 3.2.1. Interactions involving curved objects

It is often useful to know the interaction energies between surfaces
containing one or more curved surfaces: spheres, hemispheres, and things
that can be approximated as such. Given the spherical shapes of atoms,
it may be tempting to just take equations (2.3), (2.6), and (2.7) and
scale by the number of particles in each object. Unfortunately, this
will give us the wrong answer. The reason is that the centers of the
objects might be centimeters or meters away from each other. Thus, the
vast majority of atoms in any macroscopic surface contribute effectively
zero to the van der Waals interaction. Such potential energies fall off
to essentially nothing after only a few tens of nanometers.

Nevertheless, it is possible to derive equations for the interaction
energies for most geometries of particles one is likely to encounter.
For example, below is the equation for the energy between two spherical
particles of equal radii, made of the same material.

(Equation 3.1) $$W(D)=-\frac{\pi^2C_{VDW}\rho^2R}{12D}$$

where $W(D)$ is the interaction potential energy and $D$ is the distance
between the surfaces of the particles. We use a big $W$ as opposed to a
small $w$ to emphasize that these are energies between particles much
larger than atoms and molecules, and we use $D$ as the *separation
between the surfaces*. We do not use $r$, the center-to-center distance,
because the centers of two nanoscopic or macroscopic objects could be
very far from the surfaces, and do not contribute much to the total
energy. Note that the interaction energy falls off as $1/D$ rather than
the inverse factor of $r^6$ we saw for the van der Waals energy for
individual atoms and molecules (i.e., $1/r^6$). Thus, the interaction
between surfaces particles maintains its strength for relative large
distances.

### 3.2.2. The Hamaker constant

The terms for density, $\pi$, and the van der Waals coefficient,
$C_{VDW}$, appear so often in these equations that we define a new
quantity, the Hamaker constant, $A$, which contains all of these
quantities:

(Equation 3.2) $$A=\pi^2C_{VDW}\rho^2$$

Thus, the equation for the energy between two identical spheres can be
written as

(Equation 3.3) $$W(D)=-\frac{AR}{12D}$$

Each Hamaker constant comes from a unique combination of three different
materials: two of which are the two objects interacting, and the third
is the medium in which the interaction occurs (e.g., air, vacuum,
water). For example, two silicon dioxide nanoparticles interacting in
water would have the Hamaker constant $A$ $_{SiO_2-H_2O-SiO_2}$ ,
regardless of the size or shape of the particles. How do we go about
calculating the Hamaker constant, $A$? The answer is that we don't; we
look it up in a table. There are only a fairly limited number of Hamaker
constants that nanoengineers could possibly care about: particles of
silicon, gold, silver, copper, platinum, organic nanoparticles, etc.,
interacting in air, vacuum, water, or in a solvent.

Thus, the use of $A$ instead of various factors of $C_{VDW}$, $\pi$, and
$\rho$ greatly simplifies the expressions for energies between objects
larger than molecules. Most Hamaker constants are on the order of
10$^{-19}$ J in air or vacuum. The reason the Hamaker constant doesn't
vary that much between materials is that the equation for $A$ contains
two competing criteria: the van der Waals coefficient, $C_{VDW}$, and
the density $\rho$. $C_{VDW}$ is proportional to the square of the
electronic polarizability, which is proportional to the square of the
volume. On the other hand, $\rho$ is proportional to the inverse of the
volume. When $\rho$ is squared in equation (3.2), you get something
proportional to the inverse of the square of the volume. So, the two
terms roughly cancel out and you end up with some factor times
10$^{-19}$.

### 3.2.3. Converting energy to forces between surfaces

As objects get bigger and start looking more like engineering systems
than like chemical systems, we tend to become more interested in
*forces* rather than *energies*. In Chapter 2, we defined the force as
the negative rate of change of the energy with respect to interparticle
separation. Using this relationship between force and energy as before,
equation (2.2), convince yourself that the force can be written as

(Equation 3.4) $$F(D)_{sphere-sphere}=-\frac{AR}{12D^2}$$

The energy of a sphere interacting with a flat surface arises often in
nanoengineering. The round object can also be taken to be the radius of
curvature of a tip, or some microscopic bit of roughness.

(Equation 3.5) $$W(D)_{sphere-surface}=-\frac{AR}{6D}$$

As a homework assignment, see if you can derive the equation for the
force from equation (3.5).

### 3.2.4. Interactions between flat objects

Finally, consideration of the energy of two flat surfaces interacting
yields:

(Equation 3.6)
$$W(D)_{flat-flat}=-\frac{A}{12 \pi D^2} \text{ per unit area}$$

Please note that the equation for the two flat surfaces above has units
of *energy per unit area*. That is, a two-dimensional energy density.
When converted to force, we have force per unit area, which is also
called pressure:

(Equation 3.7) $$F(D)_{flat-flat}=P(D)=-\frac{A}{6\pi D^{3}}$$

Equations (3.6) and (3.7) are profound in the following sense: if the
two interacting surfaces are made of the same material, then equation
(3.6) represent the *cohesive energy density* per cross sectional area
of the material. Then, equation (3.7) is the *cohesive pressure* of two
pieces of material with perfectly smooth surfaces. For a typical van der
Waals solid like a piece of hard candy, the cohesive pressure is
huge---on the order of 1,000 atmospheres! Now, of course, if you have
two broken pieces of hard candy and, assuming they are not sticky due to
humidity or high temperature, try to stick them together, they probably
will not stick very well. Or, certainly not with 1,000 atmospheres of
pressure! On the other hand, if you take an intact piece of hard candy
and attempt to break it apart with two pairs of pliers---*without
bending it*---you will find that it is almost impossible. The reason it
will not fuse together if already broken but will be nearly impossible
to break apart if initially unbroken is not because the two scenarios
are operating under different force laws. The reason is that when
putting two pieces together, all it takes is one little nanoscale
protrusion or defect for the whole surface to be misaligned. If this
misalignment happens, the probability of every molecule on one surface
being *in van der Waals contact* with a molecule on the other surface is
vanishingly small. Thus, we don't achieve nearly the adhesive pressure
predicted by equation (3.7).

As a preview to the next chapter, the energy per unit area as shown in
equation (3.6), comes up a lot. In particular, this quantity is two
times the **surface energy density** of the two surfaces after they are
broken apart. If the material is a liquid, the surface energy density
has the same value as the **surface tension**, which is responsible for
a range of phenomena, from the spherical shape of water droplets in the
sky, to the capillarity responsible for flow in rapid antigen tests for
the coronavirus that causes COVID-19, to the mechanism by which water
striders and other animals "walk on water."

### 3.2.5. Summary of particle geometries

The scenarios described in equations (3.3) through (3.7) should cover
\>90% of scenarios you are likely to encounter in your career in
nanoengineering, and 100% of the scenarios you will encounter in this
course. Figure (3.1) depicts these scenarios.

#### Section 3: Electric double layer forces
You might wonder why---since van der Waals forces are attractive---any
solution or suspension of nanoparticles like paint or milk can be stable
at all. In fact, human cells are something like 30% solid material! If
van der Waals forces are attractive and ubiquitous, why does not all of
this solid material just clump up, sink to the bottom, or float to the
top, as the case may be? The reason is that in such suspensions, there
are repulsive forces that prevent aggregation or coagulation of the
particles. One of these forces is the **electric double layer force
(EDL)**, which occurs between all nanoparticles and surfaces in any
aqueous environment. Stated briefly and expanded upon below, the EDL
force arises because of a repulsive interaction of entropic origin. A
diffuse layer of **counterions** surrounds charged particles that are
immersed in water. Compression of these diffuse layers when two charged
particles are brought close together, as we will see, results in a
repulsive force, which keeps the particles from clumping together.

### 3.3.1. Origin of the EDL force

The EDL force arises because of the entropic repulsion of clouds of ions
which surround charged particles or surfaces. In aqueous media, any
surface placed inside will take on charges which are fixed to the
surface. These surface charges are called **co-ions**. The charge of
each co-ion is counterbalanced by a **counterion**. This pairing ensures
electrical neutrality of the entire system (that is, the bound charges
at the surface and the counterions have opposite signs). For example,
when solid particles covered in --NH $_{2}$ groups are placed in an
aqueous solution, the basic nitrogen atom (specifically its lone pair)
sucks some number of H atoms from water. This acid-base reaction
produces positively charged surfaces (-NH$_{3}^{+}$) and negatively
charged counterions (OH$^{-}$). When the solid particles are really
close, such that the outside surfaces of the particles can be
approximated as two giant parallel plates, the OH$^{-}$ groups repel
from each other against the sides of the solid particles.[^3.3.1] In
solution at a finite temperature, entropy will ensure that the OH$^{-}$
counterions diffuse some short distance away from the surface bearing
the positive charge. When the large surfaces get closer together, the
diffuse clouds of counterions get squeezed and the individual OH$^{-}$
ions have less room to move around (Figure (3.2)). Entropically, this
situation is unfavorable, so there is a net repulsive force between the
surfaces. This force gets stronger with a greater surface charge density
(more counterions). On the other hand, the force gets weaker with
increasing electrolyte (i.e., salt) concentration in the solution.

(Figure 3.2) 
>>>image(EDL.png.0)

Our treatment of the EDL force is going to be largely qualitative in
this course. Suffice it to say that for every equation for the van der
Waals interaction involving spheres interacting with spheres, spheres
interacting with flat surfaces, etc., there is a corresponding equation
for the EDL interaction. These expressions get very complicated for our
purposes (they contain, for example, the highly unusual *tanh* function)
and will not be discussed here. While we will not present any equations,
we will say that the equations for the EDL interactions depend on the
surface charge density and the electrolyte concentration in solution.
Once calculated, they return values in units of energy (J) or force (N).
To get the total energy of interaction which includes both VDW and EDL
contributions, you just add them up (see Section (3.4)).

### 3.3.2. The Debye length

The characteristic thickness of the diffuse layer of counterions is
called the **Debye length, $\kappa^{-1}$**. The Debye length is a
measure of how rapidly away from the surface the halo of counterions
decays. It is not a measure of how many ions are in the cloud to begin
with. Recall that the fundamental reason the EDL interaction is
repulsive is because of the entropic unfavorability of confining this
layer of counterions. That is, when these layers get pinched---as in the
approach of two particles---the ions lose degrees of freedom. The
repulsive force that results can be increased in one of two ways. The
first way is to pinch the halo of counterions even more so when the
particles come nearly into contact (thus reducing the entropy of the
layer in the final state). The second way is to make the layer around
each particle thicker to begin with (thus increasing the entropy of the
initial state). The easiest way to tune the thickness of the counterion
layer is by adjusting the electrolyte (i.e., salt) concentration in the
medium.

#### Reducing the EDL repulsion by "salting out"

The salt concentration in the medium has a direct effect on the
thickness of the counterion layer surrounding each surface in water.
Just like the origin of the repulsive force, the reason is entropic.
Consider the reason why the layer of counterions is diffuse to begin
with. Pure electrostatics would predict that the counterions in the gap
between particles would be pushed away from each other as far as
possible. Just as the extra electrons on a conductor push each other
apart so that they are all at the surface (think of a steel ball bearing
with a lot of extra electrons), the counterions in gaps between surfaces
push each other apart. The fact that we are in a liquid medium at a
finite temperature encourages the counterions to drift a little bit away
from the surfaces (i.e., entropy). Hold that thought.

Now, consider the addition of a bunch of extra ions---both positive and
negative, as in Na$^{+}$ and Cl$^{-}$---into the solution. With all
those extra ions around, *there are many more ways that the original
layer of counterions could remain pushed apart, pinned to the opposing
surfaces*, as predicted by electrostatics alone. So, there is a
re-balancing between the driving force of electrostatics (which want the
counterions to be pushed in a very thin layer toward the surface) and
entropy (which want the counterions to be as diffuse as possible). More
salt in solution means more microstates, overall, so there is less of an
entropic benefit for the counterions to form a diffuse layer. Thus, they
become more and more pinned to the opposing surface, and the Debye
length shrinks. As the counterion layer becomes thinner, the EDL force
becomes weaker. If the EDL force becomes weak enough, the van der Waals
force will dominate, and the surfaces will be attracted to each other on
average. This situation is called an **unstable colloid** and the
process of making colloids precipitate by increasing the electrolyte
concentration is called "salting out." The balance between EDL forces
and VDW forces is analyzed using DLVO theory, as described in the next
section.[^3.3.2]

[^3.3.1]: In introductory electromagnetism, you will learn or have learned
    that charges in a metallic object---such as a ball bearing---try to
    get as far away from each other as possible by going to the surface.
    The same thing is happening in the case of the OH$^{-}$ ions.

[^3.3.2]: A note on terminology: a "colloid" is the whole suspension,
    including the solvent. A "colloidal particle" is a single particle.

#### Section 4: DLVO forces
A suspension of nanoparticles in solution---including paint, milk,
COVID-19 vaccine formulations, and other ubiquitous products---is called
a colloid. The forces between these particles are generally a
combination of attractive forces due to van der Waals interactions and
repulsive forces due to electric double layer forces. The forces exist
independently, so to get the energy, you can add up the energies of the
VDW and EDL interactions. The total force is called the DLVO (Derjaguin,
Landau, Verwey, Overbeek) force, named after four scientists you don't
need to remember the names of but can look up on Wikipedia. You just add
up the contributions from the VDW and EDL interactions as follows:

(Equation 3.8) $$W_{DLVO}(D)=W_{VDW}(D)+W_{EDL}(D)$$

And to get the force, you can add up the forces (Equation 3.9)
$$F_{DLVO}(D)=F_{VDW}(D)+F_{EDL}(D)$$ The total energy can be plotted as
shown in Figure (3.3), below.

(Figure 3.3) 
>>>image(DLVO curve.png.0)

Each DLVO curve, from left to right, has a primary minimum, a barrier,
and a secondary minimum. Basically, if the repulsive force dominates the
interaction, then the colloid is called **stable** meaning the particles
will not aggregate, coalesce, coagulate, or **flocculate**.[^3.4.1]
Sometimes, however, the EDL force is not enough to keep the VDW force
from producing an unstable colloid, and other repulsive interactions
must be engineered into the system.
